I did not expect Sekiro in 2D, but here we are. Despite the solid souls-like gameplay mechanics or great 2D platforming sequences, to me the most impressing part of this game is that the great narrative / storytelling and unique aesthetics choice of introduction of each character. Each NPC you come across mostly changes the gameplay, hence the level design. Especially transition of modern, tech visual fxs into the cartoonish comic pages feels very appropriate.
Also every music and soundtrack in game is banger and on point, creating soothing home atmosphere to  demon crawling out of metallic robot anus vibes.
Exploration is never boring with every new mechanics learned along the story and and each rewards you deeply with hidden treasures, new shortcuts and areas, optional bosses etc. Also discovering the story while traversing everywhere and collecting lore particles there and there while solving puzzles and hack sequences was really fun. Another great tool that changes platforming is that our handy scout drone named "mystic nymph", which is needed most of the hacking sequences to unlock sideways and shortcuts. With that drone you may route your way and scout unknown areas without risking your character.
Another great point is that the safehouse, the base that you mostly chill and upgrade your items is very lively and it gets livelier with each character, every time you progress the main and side storylines. Amidst the dark nature of the story, the balance of wholesomeness is amazing to see and very motivating in player perspective.
10/10 would play the future games from the devs.

Ever since I played Ender Lillies earlier this year, I‚Äôve been playing a number of Metroidvania games, since it got me very interested in that style of video games. Nine Sols was the one I tried after the Ender games, since it was created by a studio I‚Äôve played and enjoyed games from before. Strangely, I know this studio for their horror games like Detention, so it took me until I looked at the developer name on Steam to realise it was the same people. And I‚Äôm really happy I did take notice because otherwise I would‚Äôve probably not played this til much later. Which would‚Äôve meant I‚Äôd miss out on one of the best side scrollers I‚Äôve played in years.

Nine Sols' main draw is the combat system first and foremost. The combat is surprisingly simple, comparable to Sekiro‚Äôs combat system, not just because of the parry system but also due to its simplicity. You parry and attack with either a strike, paper bomb, or projectile and use jumping and dashing for maneuvering. That‚Äôs it. But the depth comes from the number of ways you can parry, how well you can time attacks, parries, and use paper bombs effectively while dodging attacks. I adore this combat system because of how much you can do with it. The potential in bosses, enemies, and levels is unbelievable. And thankfully, they utilise their systems well and built a fantastic game around it. They don‚Äôt feel unfair, so I never found myself getting angry, just hyper-analysing what I did wrong and how I can play better.

The final boss is also a monumental feat. It applies every bit of mechanics and design displayed in the game and culminates them into a phenomenal boss that truly feels satisfying. The regular enemies have great mechanics as well. Usually, teaching the player new attacks or movement that lead into the boss of that area perfectly. There were a few enemies I didn‚Äôt like as much as the mutated enemies towards the end, but they were still fine. The game has great build variety in the forms of jades as well. These are equippables that can affect things like slash attacks or parries, or give you a new ability related to them. Challenge runs of this game are especially satisfying.

The overall level design is great, with intense platforming and combat that uses enemy placement to its advantage. It doesn‚Äôt feel unfair and has specific rhythms depending on the area. As long as you have the right rhythm, then it becomes incredibly satisfying to traverse through levels. Side quests through exploration aren‚Äôt frequent, but it feels nice to make the people in your hub happy, as well as to learn more about them. The ones related to the apemen were my favourites. Shennong‚Äôs drinking sessions were fun, and I like how the storyline ends. Shaunshaun deserves eternal happiness, so bringing him stuff to try out and learn about is incredibly wholesome. I‚Äôd die for Shaunshaun. I also found the message board secret a little emotional. I don‚Äôt have many thoughts on the story other than I really enjoyed it. Seeing the cracks in the Solarian's plans and how much they‚Äôve fucked up was deeply frustrating and depressing.

The sound design in Nine Sols is excellent. The soundtrack is great, with some excellent boss tracks, but the real standout here is the sound effects. Some of the most satisfying sound design I‚Äôve heard in an action game, which is a massive statement from me. Hearing the perfect parry sound effect is basically equal to snorting multiple lines of coke; it‚Äôs that dopamine-inducing. I expected great sound design from the people who made Detention (which you should absolutely check out), but I didn‚Äôt expect it to be THIS good.

Finally, the game‚Äôs visuals are great. The game has a very nice art style, and the overall art direction creates a memorable-looking side scroller. The backgrounds and character designs are unique and memorable as well. I NEED to get my hands on a YI plushie and especially a Shaunshaun plushie. Preferably, both made by Shaunshaun himself. There were many times when I had to stop just because of how nice a scene looked. The game also utilises horror in its visuals effectively to creep you out. It reminded me that these developers made two great horror games before they made Nine Sols. I appreciate the cozy hub in the game as well. It‚Äôs nice to just sit around, have the ambience in the back, maybe smoke a bowl with Yi while you‚Äôre at it.

I wish there were more content in Nine Sols; some bosses felt like they needed another phase, and it would have been great to have another area and story boss. Or maybe even a secret area with a secret boss. The core game is so good that I felt just the tiniest bit dissatisfied by the end. Even still, it manages to pull off almost everything it wanted to fantastic levels of quality. And I hope they make some DLC for this or a spiritual successor because they have something special with these core mechanics.

I would be satisfied if my years-long video game journey ended here. Because after years, I have finally found it. The perfect boss fight. Eigong. You raised the bar in ways I thought unimaginable.

Day 1, I go to bed after attempting you for 5 minutes. At the time, you feel impossible. A part of me feels crushed, but another eagerly waits in anticipation. You visit me in my dreams, insisting that I defeat you.

Day 2, I am able to consistently beat your first phase. I still get some tells mixed up but I understand what I need to do now. It's just a matter of making it happen.

Day 3, I struggle against your second phase. I die over and over. Your opening move feels impossible at first... But once the rhythm locks in and my hesitation dissipates... your second phase becomes even easier than the first. I'm getting closer. Just you wait, Eigong.

Day 4, I make it to your third phase. The attack I've heard horror stories of... is not as bad as I had envisioned. As long as I can get this rhythm down, you'll be a cakewalk. And it was. I defeat you. I feel half triumphant and half empty inside. Because I know that I will never be able to defeat such a magnificent boss for the first time ever again. Not once did you feel unfair. Not once did I want to ball up my fist and furiously slam my desk because of you. Instead, I accepted my error and eventually found the Skill Solution.

Eigong. I feared and questioned you. I thought that maybe you would stop me from completing this wonderful journey, but you instead granted the greatest final impression possible. You are the crown jewel of Nine Sols.

One of the best games Ive ever played, it was right up my alley. From the music, to the art, to the characters, the writing, the story, the designs, the combat, the movement, the sound design, the bosses. There was not a single part of this game that disappointed me.

I remember playing the demo a long while back. When the game first came out in full, I bought it, but then it sat unplayed for quite a long time. When I finally decided to play, it was after I had completed Silksong. All I can say to compare the two is: Nine Sols is worthy.
The story is excellent, starting out incredibly vague as to why the things in the game are happening to begin with, and eventually revealing the answers with plenty of time and clues beforehand for the player to figure most things out on their own.
The characters are fun, with my only gripe being I kinda wish there were more of them. The cast is very "efficient," with pretty much every character you can talk to being relevant to the plot.
The gameplay is very fun, with the parry-based combat always being incredibly satisfying when you manage to find the patterns and openings in a enemy's attacks.
The hand-drawn artstyle is not quite on the level of the Hollow Knight games, in my opinion, but did an excellent job giving the game its own identity. "Tao-Punk" is a very good description of the setting, being sci-fi mixed with magical elements and martial arts.

It is very worth noting: this game is hard, like REALLY hard. And the final boss (especially if you're going for the true ending) is easily the hardest part of the game, but DAMN is it satisfying to clear each challenge, or to easily take down an enemy you used to see as impossible to beat.

While the game is said to be a child of Sekiro and Hollow Knight, it is, in fact, none of that,

Why it's not Sekiro:
In Sekiro, if you perfect parry, you're winning.
In Nine Sols, if you perfect parry, you're in a stalemate.
In Sekiro, if you perfect parry, you're rewarded.
In Nine Sols, if you perfect parry, you're not PUNISHED.
The main tool the game gives you doesn't really have the capability to, when used correctly, give you the advantage in a fight. It only gives you more time.

Why it's not Hollow Knight:
The game is very linear and can't really be called a metroidvania. I've felt like I'd never had a choice where to go. I did receive new abilities, sure; (the process of which was the dullest way possible, it's just handed to you at a resting point with no effort on your part and for no apparent reason besides letting you progress) however, they really only let me go in that one area that requires that ability. There is also barely any reason to come back to already explored areas, as mostly you can collect all the stuff with the abilities you already had at that point in time. Here, I'm almost instantly executed. Sekiro dealt with that by its namesake: you could die twice. Silksong limits the damage to two masks. Dark Souls and Elden Ring didn't really have attacks this punishing, and, if in trouble, use dodge roll.

I finally picked this one up and got around to it after hearing phenomenal things and just getting off a Silksong binge, but it didn't live up to the hype at for me.

Combat was the biggest pain point. Despite claiming to be "Sekiro-like", the parry mechanics feel nothing like it. Spin kicks and charge attacks became my staples for the bulk of the game, and I found the base grounded parry extremely finnicky. For some reason the spin kick just felt objectively better at the same job. The charge parry near the end of the game is legitimately one of the worst mechanics I've ever seen in a game like this, and feels extremely counterintuitive. Visual feedback and enemy hitboxes are nonsensical - the white and red flashes hurt far more than they help because they really don't tell you anything about timing a parry or dodge, and most hitboxes are absurd and don't line up with the animations or models at all.

The final boss is such a steep hurdle compared to the rest of the game that it deserves criticism of its own. I love challenging games, I just completed a 100% steel soul run in SIlksong and I used to binge soulsbornes like nothing. This felt legitimately unfair, to the point I got so frustrated I just turned on story mode to get it over with. The game forces one particular playstyle for this boss, but the rest of the game doesn't encourage building the skillset it expects here - like I said, I relied on spin kicks and charge attacks for the bulk of the game without issue, but that's essentially useless here. Some of the other bosses were phenomenal, a few felt unfair but not egregiously so, but this one is actually absurd and feels incredibly out of place.

Skill issue, maybe, but I can't say I've ever felt this way about any other similar game.

I wish the only gripes I had were with the combat, but unfortunately the rest of the game fell flat to me too. While the aesthetic and artwork are gorgeous, a lot of animations (especially bosses) felt really off. The exploration felt severely lacking. I can't even call this a metroidvania - this game is extremely linear, and most secrets and puzzles pull from the same handful of solutions. My main example would be exploration. The map in the game lacks some real QoL features that force you to continually toggle between views in order to set a route. You can either look at the whole thing, or a singular portion, and there's no in-between. There is no ability to mark the map, so it's up to you to either take your own notes or just remember that a passage is either unexplored, out of reach, or simply blocked from progression. 

There is A LOT of story in this game, which isn't inherently a bad thing, however the flow of the game was constantly ground to a halt so that you could have minutes-long conversations. The main character himself at one point gets annoyed with having to have so many conversations. You can bet that before and after every boss-fight, you're in for several minutes of hitting A to progress. 

The combat had enough jank for me to lose interest a little over halfway through. Attacks that have purposefully animated hit-boxes will hit you when you're behind the enemy (See: Lady Ethereal, Eigong, etc.) even after/during a dodge. For a game that touts parrying/deflecting, there is very little reward it utilizing that technique. Yes, technically you can wear down an opponent with many well-timed parries and use a specific attack to deal large chunks of damage, but that attack also leaves you EXTREMELY vulnerable to the many many combos in these fights. There are also 0 i-frames after receiving damage so it's likely you'll be juggled to death, but it's basically the only way to actually capitalize on the parry mechanic as enemies do not get stunned from parrying. I wanted to DNF and then realized I was about 70% done, so I pushed through until the end, only to get the bad ending which at this point just felt like a spit in the face. 

I didn't enjoy this experience, and I felt like it just kept dragging on.

I did not enjoy this. Many elements just ruined the game for me.
On paper, it should have been great, but that's only on paper.
While the game is said to be a child of Sekiro and Hollow Knight, it is, in fact, none of that,

Why it's not Sekiro:
In Sekiro, if you perfect parry, you're winning.
In Nine Sols, if you perfect parry, you're in a stalemate.
In Sekiro, if you perfect parry, you're rewarded.
In Nine Sols, if you perfect parry, you're not PUNISHED.
The main tool the game gives you doesn't really have the capability to, when used correctly, give you the advantage in a fight. It only gives you more time.

Why it's not Hollow Knight:
The game is very linear and can't really be called a metroidvania. I've felt like I'd never had a choice where to go. I did receive new abilities, sure; (the process of which was the dullest way possible, it's just handed to you at a resting point with no effort on your part and for no apparent reason besides letting you progress) however, they really only let me go in that one area that requires that ability. There is also barely any reason to come back to already explored areas, as mostly you can collect all the stuff with the abilities you already had at that point in time. The jade system is blatantly just Hollow Knight's charms, which would be fine, that's a great system, if and only if the charms themself were useful, and most of them didn't find any use, but that may just be a me problem.

Besides that, the game has other problems. The enemy variety is barely adequate. Few areas have enemies unique to them, and most use an established roster that becomes stale. While it's unreasonable to compare it to something like Silksong's insane 200+ enemy count, this still leaves a bad taste.

And on topic of Silksong, this game is very punishing, so much more than Silksong ever was. In other Soulslikes (Silksong, Elden Ring, DS trilogy, Sekiro etc.), I can expect to reach the boss' second phase, learn a bit, and die having gained crucial knowledge. Here, I'm almost instantly executed. The lack of health (or rather the insane amounts the bosses deal) combined with punishing parry system makes for barely any time to learn boss patterns, which is, by far, the most important part for a game that tries to be like Sekiro. Sekiro dealt with that by its namesake: you could die twice. Silksong limits the damage to two masks. Dark Souls and Elden Ring didn't really have attacks this punishing, and, if in trouble, use dodge roll.
This game doesn't have anything that'd let you learn the fight. The final result will look impressive, but the path to it will be miserable and unenjoyable.

And as a personal gripe, [spoiler]Eigong's Seal attack[/spoiler] has a shit hitbox, and very frequently clips you after you've dashed through it and are a good distance away from [spoiler]her[/spoiler], akin to how bosses in DS2 could grab attack you after what would seem to be a successful dodge.
